Theology
3. Theology

In many ways Gregory was a philosopher’s theologian, because he
began with propositions from Scripture as premises for his arguments
and proceeded deductively (Brown 1998b, 200–201). In his deductive
theology, Gregory devoted much time and space to defining his terms
and exploring exhaustively the implications of possible solutions, a
practice that makes his Sentences commentary a joy to read
and a philosophical classic.

Gregory’s approach to trinitarian questions has been described
as one of “radical minimalism” (Friedman 2013, 847). Like
Walter Chatton, Robert Holkot and William of Rubio before him, Gregory
adopts Praepositinianism: the divine persons are distinct by
themselves, they are not constituted, and there are no properties
distinct from the persons. As a result, divine simplicity is
preserved, at the expense of explanation (Friedman 2013, 853–854). In
this context, Gregory ’s trinitarian theology is radically
minimalist because he went further than other defenders of
Praepositinianism (Friedman 2013, 867) in thoroughly rejecting any
principle of divine operations, therefore clearly dismissing what
Friedman calls the “psychological model,” according to
which the intellect and the will, as divine attributes, would play the
part of such principles.

In distinctions 38–41 of book I, Gregory tackled the general
problem of divine foreknowledge and future contingents and the
specific dilemma of predestination and free will. Gregory’s
positions on these questions have already been the subject of study
for many decades, and recently historians have attempted to put
Gregory into his immediate Parisian and Oxonian context. Moreover,
Gregory’s nickname, “the Torturer of Infants,” stems
in part from his stance on predestination. A discussion of
Gregory’s thought on these issues, therefore, provides a
convenient introduction both to his noetic and to his position in
history.
